title: What are some good examples to explain Occam's Razor? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you come into your home and the hallway light doesn’t work, you think the bulb has gone. If the light in the next room also doesn’t work, you think the circuit breaker has tripped. That’s because you know two bulbs failing at the same time is far less plausible than a dead circuit. That’s the core of Occam’s Razor - the simplest explanation is usually correct. To underline that, notice that as we increasingly use technology like LEDs that are much more reliable than old incandescent bulbs, your first thought might be the circuit. The service life of an LED might be 25 years, circuits trip much more frequently than that. All this shows that consciously or intuitively you’re estimating the probability of the cause of some event as you go along. Whether you did that calculation knowingly or intuitively you’re normally right. Common things are (well) more common than uncommon things and typically the common things are the simple cases with the fewest coincidences. I’d argue it’s really “the most probable explanation is usually correct” and that follows immediately from the definition of most probable. Expressed as the most probable thing is the most probable, Occam’s Razor almost reduces to a tautology. Driving Occam’s Razor by “fewest assumptions” adds in the observation that if an explanation requires more things that need to be the case it quickly diminishes in probability. Occam’s razor isn’t a law of nature. It’s pragmatic. More complicated explanations do sometimes turn out to be correct. It may be worth balancing Occam against Sherlock Holmes: When you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth. That reminds us that while the simplest explanation is normally the case it isn’t always the case.

If you can explain anything in a simple manner, it supports Occam’s Razor. But it doesn’t necessarily be right or wrong but it’ll make sense most times. Most times because concept of simplicity is sometimes subjective. An example to this will be, a religious guy says God exists because it’s written in a book that if creation is there, there should be a creator; he used to hear the voices of God; and proof exists that, this, whatever the argument is, it goes on but cannot really give a simple explanation to it or give a proof of existence at that moment to put an end to the discussion. So this argument becomes complicated. An atheist will say God doesn’t exist and he’s damn sure about it because he can’t see it, but he cannot prove that God doesn’t exist and cannot really have an end to the discussion in any way, again the things gets complicated and unnecessary arguments takes place, in other words, both have lack of simple discussions and considerations. If you see this with the eye of an Occam’s Razor, the solution for this will be “I do not know if the God exist or not.” The discussion ends there and there’s hardly any more to argue about it. It’s a very useful tool for decision making because it cuts through everything without prejudices or your predefined considerations. Like Da Vinci said and I quote, “Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.”
